title: (x) Bumble and bumble logo and labels - hand drawn {Goran}
content:
Does anyone have a clue what the scripty font is? Thanks a bunch~!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130621112546im_/http:/typophile.com/files/bb2_5784.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130621112546im_/http:/typophile.com/files/bb_6441.jpg)
author: dzgnchic

comments.content: I like the defrizz one the best. If someone knows this font and can let me know would be lovely. thank you!!

Considering there is three different "e" - it looks as if it's handmade.

Even the "Bb" is different on both labels.

OR... could it be a nice Opentype-face with lots of alternate letters?
yeah, but I'm really hoping that they're fonts..

Unfortunately I think they're hand drawn. Fortunately, there may be some alternatives out there.

- Lex

Christian Robertson's "Dear Sarah" might do the trick.

[http://www.veer.com/search/results.aspx?keyword=Sarah&producttype=TYP](http://web.archive.org/web/20130621112546/http:/www.veer.com/search/results.aspx?keyword=Sarah&producttype=TYP "http://www.veer.com/search/results.aspx?keyword=Sarah&producttype=TYP")

ChrisL
I'm waiting for Mark Simonson to do an OT version of his Felt Tip series. that would rock!

Nick Shinn has someting along those lines as well.

[http://www.shinntype.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20130621112546/http:/www.shinntype.com/ "http://www.shinntype.com")

Take a look at his "Handsome Pro"

ChrisL

speaking of which you can buy at veer now and thus use flont to preview your text:  
 [http://www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=SHT0000033](http://web.archive.org/web/20130621112546/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=SHT0000033 "http://www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=SHT0000033")

You can also check out [Part 9](http://web.archive.org/web/20130621112546/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/Script09Pg1.html) of Mike Yanega's Script ID Guide for a ton of fonts that could work.

- Lex

Pepe does really have the freedom of the original post--good find Stephen!

ChrisL
thank you all for the finds~! There are some good alternatives..Dear Sarah and the likes..but the original strokes is so free and confident which don't seem to have in most... sigh\* :/

I agree that this looks handwritten -- it's the best way to make sure you aren't copied.

In addition to Lex's remark about Part 9 of the Script Guide, you might also look at [Part 10 (Antique Handwriting)](http://web.archive.org/web/20130621112546/http:/bowfinprintworks.com/Script10Pg1.html). There are some good examples of the sort of individual flair that much modern handwriting lacks, and that may resemble this sample.

- Mike Yanega
cool~! the list is very helpful. Thank you for putting that all together! I think I will look into Baker Script. Thanks Mike!
